Patient Name: Ashok Kumar

MRD No.: 60511

Emergency No.: 3407334

Admit Date: 8th Feb 2021

Admit Time: 4:54 PM

Reason of admission: High BP 190/80

I along with the patient (my father) went to BLK Emergency ward as per the above-mentioned date and time. Dr. Sargam attended my father when his BP was 190/80 they gave medication ( Tab Amlogard 5 MG + Arkamin 5 MG ) and advise us to wait for an hour meanwhile they investigate the ECG on the side bed which was in the passing way of other patients and attendant. But god gracefully ECG was absolutely fine as per Dr. Mayank who was available at the emergency desk.

After almost 1 hr they allotted a bed (Bed No. 9) we waited patiently over there and the BP was 180/80.

Again they repeated the medicine Amrogard 5 MG around 6 pm and advise us to wait for another hour. There was no other investigation that has been made not even the temperature check by the nursing staff except the medication, ECG, and bed allotment till 7 pm. We requested them to connect the Monitor so that we can also check the BP and Pulse rate. But they paid deaf ears to all our requests and we were left with no other option. After so many requests to Dr. and nursing staff to monitor my father's BP they came up with cannula when I asked why is this needed they told me we have to inject 2 gastric infections. After this activity, they check the BP again, and it was 170/80, and then they injected one more injection to low down his BP, and that all they have done.

Around 7:15 Dr. Mayank approached us not to check my father but to advise admission, when we ask the reason he said Dr. Sargam suggested it so, but we denied it as my father was feeling perfectly fine and ECG was also fine.

He again suggested us to wait for an hour and again we waited patiently. At 8:15 we requested them to discharge my father and around 8:30 we got the bill of 6030 INR.

It was a great shock to us as we had to pay such a big amount at the emergency center for 3 tablets + 3 injections + ECG and a Cannula worth Rs 800 - 1000.

Moreover, when we saw the bill summary the 1st thing we noticed was laboratory service charges which are related to sugar added to my bill worth Rs 1370, and these investigations were never done as I was standing next to my father throughout his admission.

2nd thing we have noticed was the Triage Charges worth Rs 1800 added to my bill just to use their Emergency Bed.

3rd thing which we have noticed is the consultation fee worth Rs 600 at the emergency ward and as per my past experience I had never ever paid any consultation fee at BLK Emergency.

4th thing we have noticed was under the medical consumables section in which every higher amount of consumable is double charged.

After checking the bill copy we raised our concern to the billing department they suggested we visit and meet M.O.D, we visited him in his room and discuss the matter. He was literally shouting at me saying we really don’t like people who came up with such complaints once their patients get well. We told him to be polite and professional as we are talking about our concerns. He gave the explanation that no doctors and nurses can provide you details for the treatment to be given to your patient. He was not willing to listen to our concerns and said that I can only waive off Rs 600 from your bill now please go and pay Rs 5430.

Let me be very clear that this M.O.D was extremely rude and unprofessional. I did not want to bother my father so I paid the amount and leave the hospital.

As per my previous experience, I believed BLK was a reputed hospital and I always prefer to visit BLK for all our health issues. But this time I noticed BLK is also giving a false or dummy report for the investigations.

In my case, I received a false report for the investigation which had never happened throughout the admission. That too we receive when we questioned about the investigation charges. I have never come across such an awful experience with BLK hospital. This time I m extremely disappointed with your services, unprofessional behaviour, and unjustified charges.

I want you to go through with this case and do the needful asap. I know my rights very well so it’s a request to return my amount which you have taken unethically.

Rooms: Rooms are decent sized. 6-8 bed rooms are pathetic. No place to sleep or stand. For 3/2 rooms there is decent space but the other patient/relatives keep coming and going. shouting and having party. Even though only 1 person is allowed and only 2 are allowed during visiting hours. the crowd cannot be controlled by security. We had many fights with other people coming in huge numbers and putting TV on high volume and talking loudly. They forget that its a hospital and not their chai time masti.
Medical care: Decent. Just like other hospitals 2-3 doctors and dieticians will visit the room for no reason and make 500-600 bucks per visit. Keep check on the medicines and apparatus being brought by nurses. Take the bills which are thrown away in the cupboard.
Billing: Worst counter. Prepare yourself 1-2 weeks beforehand if you have insurance. Get all approvals done. Huge number of people standing in lines for billing.
Problems: BIGGEST problem is its blood bank. They have a blood bank that provides tested approved blood for the surgery of your patient. The problem is that they ask for as much blood from the person accompanying the patient. So, for example if your parent is admitted and has to go through surgery that day. since morning you will be hounded to give 4-5 units of blood(find other relatives who have no tattoos, BP, diabetes etc) ASAP.
There is no proof whether that much amount is being used or not. Secondly, you cannot buy that blood from them. you have to give them 4-5 units(depending on what they ask). I was shocked. when I went to the billing section they told me that the blood given to the patient goes through several tests and is 100% pure. Dr. B L Kapur, an eminent Obstetrician and Gynaecologist, set up a Charitable Hospital in 1930 at Lahore. In 1947, he moved to post-partition India and set up a Maternity Hospital at Ludhiana. In 1956 on the invitation of the then Prime Minister, Dr. B L Kapur initiated the project for setting up a 200 bed hospital in Delhi. The hospital was inaugurated by the Prime Minister, Pt. Jawahar Lal Nehru on 2nd January, 1959.

By 1984, when the hospital celebrated its Silver Jubilee, it was an expanding hospital well on its way to becoming Delhi’s premier multispecialty institute. Services offered included General Surgery, Ophthalmology, ENT, Dentistry, Pulmonology, Intensive Care and Orthopedics, apart from mother & child care.

A factor of much importance to the hospital was the health of the community. Enthusiastic doctors held camps and public health talks to improve the status of community health in the area.

In the late 1990s, the Trustees of the hospital felt the need to upgrade it to a tertiary care hospital and tied up with Radiant Life Care Private Limited to re-develop and manage the facility. Today, a modern state-of-the-art tertiary care hospital has come up in place of the old hospital. It is one of the biggest stand alone private Hospitals in the National Capital Region today.

I shudder every time I think of the 4 days I spent in BLK hospital, and I hope no one has to go through the trauma that we had to endure. My father was admitted to this hospital from 21 Mar - 24 Mar 2013, as his oncologist, a doctor for who we have a lot of respect, consults here.

On the day of admission, we were informed he needs a PET scan the next day to rule out the recurrence of cancer - however, this ultra modern hospital does not have a PET machine which they conveniently forgot to mention, and so my father - a 67 year old diabetic and cancer patient who had been admitted to the hospital in the first place for treatment of high fever and extreme weakness - was taken to Ganga Ram hospital where there were at least 10 other patients, leading to a very long and tiring wait for my father - on account of this, he was also made to stay on an empty stomach (not even any water) for nearly 10 hours, the procedure finally concluding after 3 PM!

The same day, we were informed that he needs to undergo an endoscopy and they had fixed an appointment for him for the the next day at 9AM - he was also asked to fast overnight for the endoscopy, and were told it's a very short 5 - 10 minute procedure. He was taken to the endoscopy machine room at 9 AM and my sister who was the attendant was asked to wait outside. She waited for nearly 2 hours - each time she enquired with the department nurse, she was told he was undergoing the procedure.

Finally, at 11 AM my father called my sister and informed her that he was being shuttled from one place to another and the procedure was yet to begin! When my sister confronted the attending staff, they informed her that they were cleaning the machines - can you imagine that they called a 67 year diabetic & cancer patient who could barely sit for a procedure that takes only 5 minutes and made him wait for over 2 hours to clean their machines!

Finally, it emerged that the doctor who was supposed to the procedure, a Dr Vij, had been missing and the cleaning of the machine was just an excuse, with no thought for the poor suffering patient. Finally, the procedure was completed around 12.30 PM when it could have easily been finished by 9 AM  - and on account of the delay my father had also gone without food for over 12 hours for the second consecutive day.

In between all of this, there were a whole host of tests done on my father, many of which seemed to be un-necessary to us. When we questioned the need for some of the tests - the resident doctor said that anything could be possible and they didn't want to rule anything out - of course anything is possible but the job of a doctor is to pin point the 2-3 areas that are most likely, especially when the patient has been under your observation for over 3 days.

They would take blood samples from my extremely weak father 2-3 times a day and on the evening on which we expected him to be discharged (Saturday Marrch 23) we were informed that he has low Hb and needs blood transfusion  (He had already been given two units of blood in Feb and his Hb was normal just a day ago as tested at the hospital) - maybe he wouldn't have needed this if the resident doctor was a little less eager to do all possible tests in the world. On account of the 3 hour delay in endoscopy by the hospital and the insistence of the blood transfusion, ours discharge was pushed to the next day.

On the day of discharge, I noticed that the hospital had overlooked billing for the PET scan. I was foolish enough to bring it to the attention of the billing team - as on account of their oversight we had to spend an additional 4 hours at the hospital as they send revised bills to the insurance company without bothering to explain to them that they had made a mistake in billing.

The issue finally got resolved after I made numerous calls to the insurance company and demanded that a senior person take charge. I also demanded to meet the MS or the Astt MS, but I was told both were not in hospital. Incidentally, while I was going through this nightmare in billing, another couple were loudly complaining about the ineffectiveness of the hospital.

The nursing staff in the ward is completely clueless about what is going on and also did not appear very competent  - they kept on moving the canula on my father's arm and a couple of times there was bleeding from the canula that they failed to notice and I had to call them to fix it.

And finally, the hospital security - some of the security guards behave like they are bouncers at a pub and the poor harried attendant who is running around from floor to floor on account of the sheer all-round incompetence of the hospital is treated with extreme rudeness for things like daring to forget the attendant pass!

I find nothing, absolutely nothing, to recommend about this hospital - all they have is a fancy building and LOTS of "staff" but not one of that staff is either competent or polite.

I repeat, it is better to stay at home and do nothing than go to this hospital, because going to this hospital will make you poorer in health and in bank balance.
